details.item: Relational model fundamentals and SQL-query fluency are mentioned explicitly.
Transactions, recovery, or concurrency control trade-offs are discussed.
Modern or distributed database case studies (e.g., Spanner, Aurora, NewSQL) appear.
Required primary sources (e.g., Codd 1970, System R 1976) are referenced.
At least one primary paper, timeline, or dataset citation is included inline.
Learning objectives or timeline events are tied back to cited provenance.
Explicit learning objectives and assessment signals are stated.
Includes a worked example, walkthrough, or review question.
Highlights schema practice, locking drills, or reflection prompts students can attempt.

questions.prompt: During two-phase commit across three regions, the coordinator crashes after sending PREPARE. Outline how participants remain safe, what state they persist, and how a replacement coordinator or TrueTime-based commit wait restores global ordering after recovery.
During crash recovery, outline ARIES's Analysis, Redo, and Undo phases and describe the role of LSNs and compensation log records.
A cross-region key-value store must remain available during network partitions. According to CAP, which trade-offs are forced and what compensating techniques can preserve developer sanity?

syllabus_modules.title: Relational Thinking & Data Modeling
outcomes: Introduce relational abstractions, relational algebra, and SQL basics.

syllabus_modules.title: Schema Quality & Functional Dependencies
outcomes: Use FDs, normal forms, and trade-offs between normalization and denormalization.

syllabus_modules.title: Storage Engines, Indexes, and Cost Models
outcomes: Connect physical layout choices to indexing and cost-based optimization.

syllabus_modules.title: Transactions, ACID, and Concurrency Control
outcomes: ACID guarantees, two-phase locking, deadlock handling, and isolation levels.

reading_list.title: ARIES: A Transaction Recovery Method Supporting Fine-Granularity Locking and Partial Rollbacks Using Write-Ahead Logging
reading_list.citation: mohan, (1992), ARIES: A Transaction Recovery Method Supporting Fine-Granularity Locking and Partial Rollbacks Using Write-Ahead Logging, ACM TODS

reading_list.title: Amazon Aurora: An On-Demand Relational Database Service
reading_list.citation: verbitski, (2017), Amazon Aurora: An On-Demand Relational Database Service, SIGMOD

reading_list.title: Highly Available Transactions: Virtues and Limitations
reading_list.citation: bailis, (2013), Highly Available Transactions: Virtues and Limitations, VLDB

reading_list.title: The World Beyond Batch: Streaming 101
reading_list.citation: akidau, (2017), The World Beyond Batch: Streaming 101, Communications of the ACM

reading_list.title: Concurrency Control and Recovery in Database Systems
reading_list.citation: bernstein, (1987), Concurrency Control and Recovery in Database Systems, Addison-Wesley

timeline.summary: Formalizes data independence and relational algebra.
Formalizes data independence and relational algebra.

exercise_ideas.title: Exercise · Quiz-Sql-Group
exercise_ideas.description: Given Relations Orders(order_id, customer_id, total) and Customers(customer_id, region), write SQL to return each region with average order total for customers placing >=5 orders.
exercise_ideas.expected_outcome: Declarative data definition/manipulation statements derived from relational algebra.; Cost models, statistics, and plan enumeration via Selinger- and Volcano-style search.

exercise_ideas.title: Exercise · Quiz-Normalization
exercise_ideas.description: A table Campaign(channel, campaign_id, region, manager, region_manager_email) exhibits repeated manager info. Show how to reach BCNF and justify the functional dependencies you used.
exercise_ideas.expected_outcome: Attribute determinism rules that shape candidate keys and decomposition choices.; 1NF through BCNF plus practical heuristics for when to denormalize.

exercise_ideas.title: Exercise · Quiz-Locking
exercise_ideas.description: Explain how strict two-phase locking prevents dirty reads yet can deadlock. Provide a concrete deadlock example and mitigation.
exercise_ideas.expected_outcome: Two-phase locking, timestamp ordering, optimistic control, and conflict handling.; ACID semantics, atomic commit boundaries, and application-facing APIs.

explanations.heading: Distributed & Replicated Systems (distributed)
explanations.body_md: Scale-out topologies, consensus, and geo-distributed SQL.

explanations.heading: Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP) (htap)
explanations.body_md:
Systems blending OLTP + analytics via log-based replication and materialized views.

*History.* 2017: Aurora details HTAP replication. Blends OLTP durability with analytical replicas via log shipping.

explanations.heading: CAP Theorem (cap_theorem)
explanations.body_md: Under partitions, systems trade availability against consistency.

explanations.heading: Replication & Sharding (replication_and_sharding)
explanations.body_md: Leader/follower, multi-leader, and partitioning schemes for scale and resilience.

concepts.name: Foundations & Modeling
concepts.summary: Canonical abstractions (ER diagrams, relations, relational algebra) that separate logical from physical design.

concepts.name: Execution & Storage
concepts.summary: Physical layout, indexing, and query processing internals.

concepts.name: Transactions & Concurrency
concepts.summary: Guarantees that keep shared data correct when multiple writers/readers interact.

spotlight_paper.title: A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks
